intro: Gilia atractyloides var. macrantha, commonly known as the showy gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant produces showy, clustered flowers that are typically pink to purple in color, blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and hairy, and the plant is often found in rocky or sandy soils. It is adapted to arid environments and is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance.
